Assess lung sounds and interpret new crackles or worsening work of breathing
Encourage oral fluid intake and record I&O
items.rationale: UAP may collect routine vital signs, assist with positioning/turning, and support hydration while the RN provides teaching, assesses/interpret clinical changes, and makes nursing judgments.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Reduction of Risk Potential
items.stem: The nurse reviews provider orders for the client with suspected pneumonia. Indicate whether each action should be completed before the first antibiotic dose when possible or can occur after antibiotics are started.
rows: Administer first dose of empiric antibiotic
Start supplemental oxygen for SpO2 90% on room air
items.rationale: Cultures are ideally obtained before antibiotics to improve diagnostic yield. Oxygen should not be delayed for cultures. Chest x-ray and antibiotic administration should proceed promptly; imaging can occur after antibiotics are initiated if needed to avoid treatment delay.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Physiological Adaptation
items.stem: Evolving case: Pneumonia with worsening respiratory status.

stages.update: Initial assessment: T 38.9°C, HR 108, RR 24, BP 132/78, SpO2 90% on room air; crackles in RLL; productive cough.

question.stem: Which nursing action is the priority?
options: Obtain a sputum specimen for culture
Apply supplemental oxygen
Administer acetaminophen for fever
Encourage oral fluids

stages.rationale: Hypoxemia (SpO2 90%) requires immediate intervention to improve oxygenation. Cultures and other supportive care are important but not first over airway/breathing.

stages.update: After 2 L/min nasal cannula, SpO2 improves to 93%. The provider orders blood cultures x2, sputum culture, CBC, BMP, and IV antibiotics.

question.stem: Which actions should the nurse take to support accurate culture results and timely therapy? Select all that apply.
options: Draw blood cultures before starting antibiotics when possible
Collect sputum sample after antibiotics to reduce coughing
Label specimens at the bedside with two identifiers
Delay antibiotics until chest x-ray is resulted
Send specimens to the lab promptly after collection

stages.rationale: Cultures should be obtained prior to antibiotics when feasible, specimens must be correctly labeled at bedside, and prompt transport maintains specimen integrity. Antibiotics should not be delayed for imaging; sputum is best collected before antibiotics.

stages.update: Four hours later the client is more confused and restless. Vitals: T 39.2°C, HR 122, RR 30, BP 94/58, SpO2 89% on 2 L/min; urine output decreased.

question.stem: Which provider order should the nurse implement first?
options: Increase oxygen and prepare for possible escalation of respiratory support
Administer PRN cough suppressant
Provide a snack and recheck glucose in 1 hour
Ambulate in hallway to mobilize secretions

stages.rationale: Findings suggest clinical deterioration and possible sepsis/respiratory failure. Immediate stabilization of oxygenation/ventilation and rapid escalation are priority; cough suppression, snacks, and ambulation are unsafe at this time.

items.rationale: The client’s course demonstrates pneumonia that can progress to hypoxemia and sepsis; nursing priorities focus on airway/breathing, timely cultures/antibiotics, and rapid recognition and response to deterioration.

items.client_need: Safe and Effective Care Environment: Safety and Infection Control
items.stem: Evolving case: Infection control and discharge teaching for pneumonia.

stages.update: The client is admitted with suspected community-acquired pneumonia and a productive cough. No history of recent hospitalization. No known drug allergies.

question.stem: Which isolation precautions are appropriate initially?
options: Airborne precautions (N95)
Droplet precautions with surgical mask
Contact precautions only
No precautions are needed

stages.rationale: For suspected pneumonia with cough, droplet precautions are appropriate until transmissible etiologies are ruled out per policy. Airborne is reserved for pathogens like TB/measles/varicella; contact may be added for certain organisms or uncontrolled secretions.

stages.update: After 48 hours of treatment, the client is improving and preparing for discharge on oral antibiotics. The client has type 2 diabetes and reduced appetite.

question.stem: Which discharge instructions should the nurse include? Select all that apply.
options: Finish the full course of antibiotics even if feeling better
Increase fluids (if not contraindicated) and use coughing/deep breathing to clear secretions
Stop metformin until the antibiotic course is complete
Return for care urgently if increased shortness of breath, chest pain, confusion, or persistent fever
Avoid all activity until cough is completely gone

stages.rationale: Key teaching includes completing antibiotics, pulmonary hygiene/hydration, and recognizing worsening symptoms. Metformin should not be stopped solely due to antibiotics without provider direction. Gradual activity as tolerated is usually encouraged rather than complete avoidance.

stages.update: The client asks how to reduce spreading illness to family members at home.

question.stem: Which instruction is most appropriate?
options: Share utensils only after rinsing with water
Wear a mask when around others and perform frequent hand hygiene
Stop coughing by taking over-the-counter antitussives around family
Disinfect hands only after meals

stages.rationale: Mask use when symptomatic and consistent hand hygiene reduce droplet transmission. Sharing utensils is not recommended without proper washing. Suppressing cough is not a primary infection-control strategy. Hand hygiene is needed frequently, not only after meals.

items.rationale: Nursing care includes implementing appropriate precautions during suspected infectious respiratory illness and providing evidence-based discharge teaching to prevent relapse and reduce transmission.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Reduction of Risk Potential
items.stem: An adult arrives to the ER with sudden dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain. Vitals: T 36.9°C, HR 120, RR 28, BP 110/70, SpO2 88% on room air. Which action should the nurse take first?
options: Apply oxygen and elevate the head of bed
Obtain a 12-lead ECG
Draw blood for D-dimer
Prepare the client for a chest CT with contrast
items.correct: Apply oxygen and elevate the head of bed
items.rationale: The priority is to correct hypoxemia and support ventilation. Oxygen and positioning are immediate, nursing-controlled interventions while diagnostic testing can occur after stabilization.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Reduction of Risk Potential
items.stem: The nurse suspects a pulmonary embolism (PE) in this postoperative client with sudden dyspnea, pleuritic pain, tachycardia, and SpO2 88% on room air. Which diagnostic test is most appropriate to confirm a PE?
options: Chest X-ray
CT pulmonary angiography
Sputum culture
Pulmonary function tests
items.correct: CT pulmonary angiography
items.rationale: CT pulmonary angiography is the most commonly used confirmatory test for PE in a hemodynamically stable client. Chest X-ray may be normal or nonspecific and does not confirm PE.
items.image_prompt: A realistic hospital CT suite scene showing a client on a CT table with IV contrast setup and a monitor visible; no identifiable patient features; educational medical illustration style.
items.image_caption: CT pulmonary angiography is commonly used to confirm suspected pulmonary embolism.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Pharmacological and Parenteral Therapies
items.stem: The provider suspects pulmonary embolism and prescribes IV unfractionated heparin. Which nursing action is the best priority before starting the infusion?
options: Obtain baseline aPTT (or anti-Xa per protocol) and assess for bleeding risk
Ask the client to ambulate in the hallway to prevent venous stasis
Administer aspirin to reduce platelet aggregation
Restrict oral fluids to reduce pulmonary edema
items.correct: Obtain baseline aPTT (or anti-Xa per protocol) and assess for bleeding risk
items.rationale: Heparin requires baseline coagulation assessment and bleeding-risk screening to guide safe dosing and monitoring. Ambulation is not appropriate in an unstable, hypoxemic client; aspirin and fluid restriction are not primary interventions for PE.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Physiological Adaptation
items.stem: After oxygen is applied, the client becomes more anxious and states, "I can't breathe," with increasing work of breathing. Which action should the nurse take first?
options: Notify the rapid response team/provider and prepare for advanced airway/ventilatory support
Encourage slow deep breathing and recheck SpO2 in 10 minutes
Administer an oral anxiolytic as prescribed
Place the client supine with legs elevated
items.correct: Notify the rapid response team/provider and prepare for advanced airway/ventilatory support
items.rationale: Worsening respiratory distress may signal deterioration requiring escalation (high-flow oxygen, noninvasive ventilation, or intubation). Delaying care for reassurance or oral medication is unsafe; supine positioning can worsen ventilation.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Reduction of Risk Potential
items.stem: Which assessment finding in this client is most consistent with pulmonary embolism?
options: Sudden onset dyspnea with tachycardia and pleuritic chest pain
Productive cough with fever and coarse crackles
Chest pain relieved by leaning forward with diffuse ST elevation
Slow onset dyspnea with bilateral pitting edema and orthopnea
items.correct: Sudden onset dyspnea with tachycardia and pleuritic chest pain
items.rationale: PE commonly presents with acute dyspnea, tachycardia, hypoxemia, anxiety, and pleuritic chest pain. The other options align more with pneumonia, pericarditis, or heart failure.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Reduction of Risk Potential
items.stem: Which nursing assessment is most important to perform to help identify the source of the suspected embolus?
options: Assess the legs for unilateral swelling, warmth, and pain
Inspect the abdomen for distention and bowel sounds
Test hand grasps and pupil response
Auscultate for a new heart murmur at the apex
items.correct: Assess the legs for unilateral swelling, warmth, and pain
items.rationale: Most PEs originate from deep vein thrombosis in the lower extremities. Assessing for DVT signs helps identify the likely source and guides prevention of further emboli.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Physiological Adaptation
items.stem: The client with suspected PE suddenly becomes hypotensive and more hypoxic. Which medication order should the nurse anticipate as the priority if massive PE is suspected and there are no contraindications?
options: IV thrombolytic therapy (e.g., alteplase)
Oral warfarin
Inhaled corticosteroid
IV furosemide
items.correct: IV thrombolytic therapy (e.g., alteplase)
items.rationale: Hemodynamic instability with suspected massive PE may require urgent reperfusion with thrombolytics if no contraindications. Warfarin is not immediate; inhaled steroids and diuretics do not treat PE.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Pharmacological and Parenteral Therapies
items.stem: The client is receiving IV heparin for suspected PE. Which finding is most important for the nurse to report immediately?
options: New onset hematuria
Mild bruising at the IV site
Heart rate of 104/min
Client reports hunger
items.correct: New onset hematuria
items.rationale: Hematuria may indicate significant bleeding while on anticoagulation and requires immediate evaluation and potential adjustment/holding of therapy. Mild bruising can occur; the other findings are not urgent.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Basic Care and Comfort
items.stem: Which nursing intervention best helps decrease oxygen demand in this anxious client with suspected PE?
options: Maintain bed rest and cluster nursing care
Encourage the client to cough and deep breathe every 5 minutes
Ambulate the client to reduce anxiety
Provide a large meal to improve energy
items.correct: Maintain bed rest and cluster nursing care
items.rationale: Bed rest and clustering care minimize exertion and reduce oxygen consumption during acute hypoxemia. Frequent forced coughing, ambulation, and large meals can increase oxygen demand.

items.client_need: Safe and Effective Care Environment: Management of Care
items.stem: The nurse is triaging clients in the ER. Which client should be seen first?
options: Postoperative client with sudden dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, HR 120, RR 28, SpO2 88% on room air
Client with a sprained ankle and pain rated 8/10
Client with a sore throat and temperature 38.1°C
Client with chronic back pain requesting a medication refill
items.correct: Postoperative client with sudden dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, HR 120, RR 28, SpO2 88% on room air
items.rationale: This client has signs of a potentially life-threatening PE with hypoxemia and tachypnea and requires immediate stabilization and evaluation. The other conditions are lower acuity.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Reduction of Risk Potential
items.stem: An adult arrives to the ER with sudden shortness of breath, pleuritic chest pain, anxiety, HR 120, RR 28, BP 110/70, and SpO2 88% on room air. The client had recent surgery. Which interpretation is most accurate?
options: Acute pulmonary embolism causing ventilation-perfusion mismatch
Acute coronary syndrome causing myocardial ischemia
Tension pneumothorax causing mediastinal shift
Acute asthma exacerbation causing bronchospasm
items.correct: Acute pulmonary embolism causing ventilation-perfusion mismatch
items.rationale: Sudden dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, tachycardia, hypoxemia, and recent surgery (VTE risk) most strongly suggest acute pulmonary embolism with V/Q mismatch.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Reduction of Risk Potential
items.stem: The nurse suspects pulmonary embolism. Which assessment finding on a lower-extremity exam most supports the suspected source of embolus?
options: Unilateral calf swelling with warmth and tenderness
Bilateral ankle edema that improves with elevation
Cool, pale foot with diminished pedal pulses
Symmetric calf soreness after exercise
items.correct: Unilateral calf swelling with warmth and tenderness
items.rationale: Most PEs originate from a DVT; unilateral swelling, warmth, and tenderness are classic DVT findings.
items.image_prompt: Create a clinical illustration showing a comparison of two lower legs: one leg normal and the other with visible unilateral calf swelling and redness/erythema. Include subtle labeling lines pointing to 'swelling' and 'warmth/redness' without any identifying patient features.
items.image_caption: Unilateral calf swelling and erythema consistent with possible DVT.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Physiological Adaptation
items.stem: The client is dyspneic with SpO2 88% on room air and is anxious. What is the nurse’s priority first action?
options: Apply oxygen and titrate to maintain SpO2 at least 92% (or per facility protocol)
Place the client in Trendelenburg position
Obtain a detailed surgical history and medication list
Encourage the client to cough and deep breathe every hour
items.correct: Apply oxygen and titrate to maintain SpO2 at least 92% (or per facility protocol)
items.rationale: Airway/breathing is the priority; immediate supplemental oxygen treats hypoxemia while further diagnostics and therapies are arranged.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Reduction of Risk Potential
items.stem: Which diagnostic test is most likely to confirm a pulmonary embolism in this hemodynamically stable client?
options: CT pulmonary angiography
Chest x-ray
12-lead ECG
Sputum culture
items.correct: CT pulmonary angiography
items.rationale: CT pulmonary angiography is the most commonly used confirmatory imaging test for PE in stable clients; chest x-ray and ECG may show nonspecific changes.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Pharmacological and Parenteral Therapies
items.stem: The provider prescribes IV unfractionated heparin for suspected pulmonary embolism. Which nursing action is best before initiating the infusion?
options: Verify baseline aPTT/anti-Xa and platelet count
Administer vitamin K to reduce bleeding risk
Hold oxygen until anticoagulation is started
Encourage ambulation to improve venous return
items.correct: Verify baseline aPTT/anti-Xa and platelet count
items.rationale: Baseline coagulation status and platelets are needed to safely start and monitor heparin and to screen for thrombocytopenia risk.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Physiological Adaptation
items.stem: After initial interventions, the client becomes more hypotensive and diaphoretic (BP 84/50), with increasing respiratory distress. What is the nurse’s priority action?
options: Activate the rapid response team and notify the provider immediately
Schedule the client for an incentive spirometry teaching session
Obtain a stool sample for occult blood
Prepare the client for discharge teaching on anticoagulants
items.correct: Activate the rapid response team and notify the provider immediately
items.rationale: Acute deterioration with hypotension suggests massive PE and shock; this is a medical emergency requiring immediate escalation and resuscitative management.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Reduction of Risk Potential
items.stem: Which arterial blood gas (ABG) pattern is most consistent with early pulmonary embolism in this client?
options: pH 7.48, PaCO2 30 mm Hg, PaO2 60 mm Hg
pH 7.30, PaCO2 55 mm Hg, PaO2 55 mm Hg
pH 7.36, PaCO2 40 mm Hg, PaO2 95 mm Hg
pH 7.20, PaCO2 70 mm Hg, PaO2 45 mm Hg
items.correct: pH 7.48, PaCO2 30 mm Hg, PaO2 60 mm Hg
items.rationale: Early PE commonly causes hypoxemia with respiratory alkalosis from hyperventilation (low PaCO2, elevated pH).

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Pharmacological and Parenteral Therapies
items.stem: The client asks why anticoagulation is needed for a pulmonary embolism. Which response by the nurse is best?
options: “It helps prevent the clot from getting larger and reduces the risk of new clots forming while your body breaks down the existing clot.”
“It immediately dissolves the clot in your lung so your breathing will return to normal within minutes.”
“It replaces oxygen in your blood and treats the low oxygen level.”
“It prevents chest pain by relaxing the muscles around your lungs.”
items.correct: “It helps prevent the clot from getting larger and reduces the risk of new clots forming while your body breaks down the existing clot.”
items.rationale: Anticoagulants do not directly dissolve clots; they prevent propagation and recurrence while endogenous fibrinolysis resolves the thrombus.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Reduction of Risk Potential
items.stem: Which findings in this client are consistent with pulmonary embolism? Select all that apply.
options: Sudden onset dyspnea
Pleuritic chest pain
Tachycardia
SpO2 88% on room air
Bradycardia with bounding pulse
correct: Sudden onset dyspnea
Pleuritic chest pain
Tachycardia
SpO2 88% on room air
items.rationale: PE commonly presents with abrupt dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, tachycardia, and hypoxemia; bradycardia with bounding pulse is not typical.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Reduction of Risk Potential
items.stem: The nurse is caring for a client receiving IV heparin for suspected pulmonary embolism. Which actions are appropriate? Select all that apply.
options: Use an infusion pump for the heparin infusion
Monitor for bleeding (gums, urine, stool, bruising)
Assess platelet count for possible heparin-induced thrombocytopenia
Administer IM injections to avoid repeated venipunctures
Implement bleeding precautions (soft toothbrush, electric razor)
correct: Use an infusion pump for the heparin infusion
Monitor for bleeding (gums, urine, stool, bruising)
Assess platelet count for possible heparin-induced thrombocytopenia
Implement bleeding precautions (soft toothbrush, electric razor)
items.rationale: Heparin requires precise dosing and close monitoring for bleeding and HIT; IM injections increase hematoma risk and should be avoided when possible.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Reduction of Risk Potential
items.stem: The nurse suspects pulmonary embolism (PE) in a postoperative client with sudden dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, HR 120/min, RR 28/min, and SpO2 88% on room air. Which additional assessments are most consistent with PE? Select all that apply.
options: New onset hemoptysis
Unilateral calf swelling, warmth, and tenderness
Sudden onset anxiety/feeling of impending doom
Diffuse bilateral crackles that improve after coughing
Syncope or near-syncope
Bradycardia with bounding pulses
items.rationale: PE commonly presents with sudden dyspnea, pleuritic pain, tachycardia, hypoxemia, anxiety, hemoptysis, and may cause syncope from obstructive shock. Unilateral calf findings suggest DVT as the source. Diffuse crackles improving with cough suggest secretion-related atelectasis/bronchitis; bradycardia with bounding pulses is not typical of PE.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Pharmacological and Parenteral Therapies
items.stem: The provider prescribes interventions for suspected acute pulmonary embolism. Which nursing actions are appropriate to implement immediately? Select all that apply.
options: Apply oxygen to maintain SpO2 at least 92% (or per order)
Initiate continuous cardiac monitoring
Establish/verify IV access for labs and medications
Encourage ambulation to prevent venous stasis
Prepare to administer anticoagulation as ordered after assessing bleeding risk
Place the client in high-Fowler position and limit unnecessary activity
items.rationale: Immediate nursing priorities include supporting oxygenation, monitoring for dysrhythmias/hemodynamic changes, establishing IV access, minimizing oxygen demand, and preparing for anticoagulation per orders with bleeding-risk assessment. Ambulation is avoided in suspected/known PE or DVT due to risk of worsening embolization and to reduce cardiopulmonary demand.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Management of Care
items.stem: The client suddenly becomes more dyspneic with SpO2 84% on room air and appears panicked. Order the nurse’s priority actions.
options: Apply high-flow oxygen and titrate per protocol/order
Raise the head of bed and maintain bedrest
Activate rapid response/notify the provider of suspected PE deterioration
Obtain vital signs and focused cardiopulmonary assessment
Prepare for diagnostic testing and treatment (e.g., ECG, labs, CT angiography; anticoagulation)
items.rationale: Positioning and activity restriction reduce work of breathing and demand; oxygenation support follows immediately. Next, reassess vitals and focused status to quantify severity, then activate rapid response/notify provider to expedite escalation and orders. Preparation for diagnostics and treatment follows once immediate stabilization and notification are underway.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Reduction of Risk Potential
items.stem: The provider orders a CT pulmonary angiogram with IV contrast for suspected PE. Place the nursing actions in the correct order.
options: Assess for history of contrast reaction and current renal risk factors; review creatinine/eGFR if available
Verify patent large-bore IV access and ensure appropriate gauge/site for contrast injection
Explain the procedure and the sensation of warmth/metallic taste; verify informed consent per facility policy
Remove metal objects and prepare the client for transport with oxygen and monitoring as needed
Post-procedure: monitor for signs of contrast reaction and assess the IV site for infiltration/extravasation
items.rationale: Safety preparation begins with screening for contrast allergy and renal risk, then ensuring appropriate IV access for contrast. Client teaching and consent verification occur before transport. Transport is arranged with needed oxygen/monitoring. After the scan, monitor for contrast reaction and IV complications.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Pharmacological and Parenteral Therapies
items.stem: The nurse begins an IV unfractionated heparin infusion for suspected PE. A critical nursing safety assessment before initiating therapy is to verify the client has no evidence of active ________.
items.rationale: Heparin increases bleeding risk; initiating therapy requires assessment for active bleeding (e.g., GI bleed, hematuria, intracranial bleed symptoms) and baseline labs per protocol to reduce harm.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Reduction of Risk Potential
items.stem: For acute PE, a key expected finding on arterial blood gas due to hyperventilation is decreased PaCO2 (respiratory ________).
items.rationale: Acute PE often causes tachypnea and hyperventilation, leading to decreased PaCO2 and respiratory alkalosis early in the course, along with hypoxemia from V/Q mismatch.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Reduction of Risk Potential
items.stem: The nurse is reviewing anticipated findings in pulmonary embolism (PE) compared with myocardial infarction (MI). Match each finding with the condition it most strongly suggests.
rows: Pleuritic chest pain worse with inspiration
ST-segment elevation in a coronary distribution on ECG
Sudden dyspnea with hypoxemia out of proportion to chest exam
Elevated troponin with crushing substernal pressure radiating to jaw/arm
items.rationale: PE classically causes pleuritic pain and unexplained hypoxemia with relatively minimal lung findings, while MI is suggested by ischemic ECG patterns and typical pressure-like chest pain with troponin elevation.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Pharmacological and Parenteral Therapies
items.stem: The nurse plans care for a client receiving anticoagulation for PE. Indicate whether each nursing action is appropriate.
rows: Use an electric razor and soft toothbrush
Administer IM injections to reduce IV access complications
Implement fall precautions and assist with ambulation
Hold pressure longer after venipuncture/IV removal
Give aspirin for pleuritic pain without notifying the provider
items.rationale: Anticoagulation increases bleeding risk; minimize trauma (electric razor/soft toothbrush), avoid IM injections due to hematoma risk, prevent falls, and apply prolonged pressure after punctures. Aspirin adds antiplatelet effect and should not be given without provider direction in an anticoagulated client.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Management of Care
items.stem: Evolving case: suspected pulmonary embolism in the ER.

stages.update: A postoperative client reports sudden shortness of breath and pleuritic chest pain. Vitals: T 36.9°C, HR 120, RR 28, BP 110/70, SpO2 88% on room air. Client is anxious.

question.stem: What is the nurse’s priority initial intervention?
options: Encourage coughing and deep breathing
Apply supplemental oxygen
Obtain a 12-lead ECG
Start IV antibiotics

stages.rationale: Hypoxemia is present (SpO2 88%); immediate oxygen therapy is the priority to support oxygenation while further evaluation proceeds.

stages.update: After oxygen via nonrebreather, SpO2 improves to 93%. The provider orders IV heparin and CT pulmonary angiography. The client asks why a blood thinner is needed.

question.stem: Which explanation by the nurse is most accurate?
options: “Heparin will dissolve the clot immediately.”
“Heparin helps prevent the clot from getting larger and reduces new clot formation.”
“Heparin will replace oxygen and improve breathing right away.”
“Heparin prevents pneumonia after surgery.”

stages.rationale: Heparin anticoagulates to prevent clot propagation and additional thrombus formation; it does not directly lyse the existing embolus or replace oxygen.

stages.update: While awaiting CT, the client becomes pale and diaphoretic. BP drops to 82/54, HR 132, SpO2 90% on oxygen. The client reports worsening chest pain and dizziness.

question.stem: Which actions should the nurse take immediately? Select all that apply.
options: Activate rapid response and notify the provider of suspected massive PE
Increase oxygen support as needed and prepare for advanced airway support per protocol
Place the client supine with legs elevated if tolerated and no respiratory compromise
Stop all IV fluids to avoid pulmonary edema
Prepare to administer vasopressors and thrombolytic therapy per orders/protocol

stages.rationale: Hypotension with suspected PE suggests obstructive shock (possible massive PE), requiring rapid escalation, optimized oxygenation/ventilation readiness, and preparation for hemodynamic support and potential thrombolysis per orders. Routine leg elevation is not prioritized and may worsen dyspnea; IV fluids are often used cautiously to support preload rather than stopped reflexively.

items.rationale: This evolving scenario tests prioritization: oxygenation first, understanding of anticoagulation purpose, and rapid escalation/treatment readiness when signs of massive PE and shock develop.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Reduction of Risk Potential
items.stem: Evolving case: monitoring and complication prevention during treatment for PE.

stages.update: CT confirms acute pulmonary embolism. The client is started on IV unfractionated heparin per protocol. Baseline labs are drawn.

question.stem: Which laboratory value is most important for the nurse to trend to titrate the heparin infusion per protocol?
options: INR
aPTT or anti-Xa level
Platelet count only
D-dimer

stages.rationale: Unfractionated heparin is titrated using aPTT or anti-Xa per facility protocol. INR is used for warfarin monitoring; platelets are monitored for HIT but do not titrate the infusion alone; D-dimer is not used to manage therapy.

stages.update: Six hours later, the client reports new back/flank pain and the urine appears pink-tinged. BP is 98/62, HR 118. The heparin infusion is running.

question.stem: What is the nurse’s priority action?
options: Document and reassess in 2 hours
Stop the heparin infusion and notify the provider immediately
Give PRN NSAID for pain
Encourage oral fluids and continue the infusion

stages.rationale: New pain with hematuria suggests bleeding while on heparin. The priority is to stop the anticoagulant per protocol and notify the provider for urgent evaluation and potential reversal/diagnostics.

stages.update: The provider discontinues heparin temporarily and orders additional labs. Platelets decrease from 220,000/mm3 to 92,000/mm3 compared with baseline.

question.stem: Which nursing actions are appropriate based on this trend? Select all that apply.
options: Suspect heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) and notify the provider immediately
Prepare to administer platelet transfusion routinely
Anticipate orders to avoid all heparin products and switch to a non-heparin anticoagulant
Assess for new thrombosis (e.g., limb pain/swelling, chest pain, neurologic changes)
Restart heparin because platelets are still above 50,000/mm3

stages.rationale: A significant platelet drop after heparin exposure raises concern for HIT, which is prothrombotic and requires stopping all heparin and using an alternative anticoagulant; the nurse should assess for new thrombosis and escalate promptly. Platelet transfusion is not routine unless life-threatening bleeding; restarting heparin is contraindicated when HIT is suspected.

items.rationale: This evolving scenario evaluates safe heparin titration monitoring, recognition of bleeding, and identification/management priorities for suspected HIT.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Reduction of Risk Potential
items.stem: An adult client with a history of asthma arrives to the ED with diffuse wheezing, speaking in short phrases, RR 32/min, HR 118/min, and SpO2 89% on room air. Which action should the nurse take first?
options: Place the client on high-Fowler position and apply oxygen
Obtain a peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR) measurement
Initiate IV access and draw blood for labs
Prepare the client for a chest x-ray
items.correct: Place the client on high-Fowler position and apply oxygen
items.rationale: The client is hypoxemic (SpO2 89% RA) with signs of respiratory distress; the priority is to support airway/breathing and improve oxygenation immediately. PEFR and diagnostics can follow once the client is stabilized.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Physiological Adaptation
items.stem: Based on the assessment findings, which interpretation is most accurate?
options: The client is experiencing an acute asthma exacerbation with impaired gas exchange
The client likely has a pneumothorax causing unilateral loss of breath sounds
The client is having an anaphylactic reaction due to a new allergy
The client is experiencing heart failure with pulmonary edema
items.correct: The client is experiencing an acute asthma exacerbation with impaired gas exchange
items.rationale: Diffuse wheeze, tachypnea, inability to speak full sentences, anxiety, and low SpO2 are classic for acute asthma exacerbation with ventilation-perfusion mismatch and hypoxemia. Pneumothorax is typically unilateral with diminished/absent sounds; anaphylaxis includes hypotension, urticaria, angioedema; pulmonary edema commonly presents with crackles and pink frothy sputum.
items.image_prompt: Create a realistic clinical photo-style image of an adult sitting upright in an emergency department bed, appearing anxious and mildly diaphoretic, using accessory muscles to breathe. A pulse oximeter on the finger displays 89%. A bedside monitor shows tachycardia. No staff faces visible.
items.image_caption: Client in respiratory distress with low oxygen saturation in the emergency department.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Pharmacological and Parenteral Therapies
items.stem: After applying oxygen, which prescribed therapy should the nurse anticipate administering next to relieve bronchospasm?
options: Nebulized albuterol
Oral acetaminophen
IV furosemide
Oral propranolol
items.correct: Nebulized albuterol
items.rationale: Short-acting beta2-agonists (e.g., albuterol) are first-line rescue medications for acute bronchospasm in asthma exacerbations. The other options do not treat acute asthma and propranolol can worsen bronchospasm.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Reduction of Risk Potential
items.stem: The client is still speaking in short phrases and appears anxious. Which assessment should the nurse obtain next to best determine severity and response to treatment?
options: Peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR) or FEV1 if able
Abdominal girth measurement
12-lead ECG to rule out dysrhythmia
Daily weight compared to baseline
items.correct: Peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR) or FEV1 if able
items.rationale: Objective airflow measurement (PEFR/FEV1) helps grade severity of asthma exacerbation and monitor response to bronchodilator therapy. The other assessments do not directly quantify airflow obstruction in asthma.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Reduction of Risk Potential
items.stem: Which finding in this client most strongly indicates a moderate-to-severe asthma exacerbation?
options: Speaking in short phrases
Temperature 37.1°C (98.8°F)
Blood pressure 128/80 mm Hg
History of asthma treated with a rescue inhaler
items.correct: Speaking in short phrases
items.rationale: Inability to speak full sentences reflects significant work of breathing and airflow limitation. Normal temperature and blood pressure do not indicate severity, and history alone does not describe current exacerbation severity.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Pharmacological and Parenteral Therapies
items.stem: In addition to short-acting bronchodilators, which medication class should the nurse anticipate to reduce airway inflammation during this acute episode?
options: Systemic corticosteroids
Antitussives
Beta-blockers
Loop diuretics
items.correct: Systemic corticosteroids
items.rationale: Systemic corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone, methylprednisolone) decrease airway inflammation and are standard therapy for moderate-to-severe asthma exacerbations. Antitussives are not indicated; beta-blockers may worsen bronchospasm; diuretics are not used for asthma.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Physiological Adaptation
items.stem: After initial treatments, which finding would require the nurse to notify the provider immediately and prepare for possible intubation?
options: Diminished or absent breath sounds with increasing drowsiness
Heart rate decreases from 118 to 100/min
SpO2 improves from 89% to 94% with oxygen
Client reports chest tightness is improving
items.correct: Diminished or absent breath sounds with increasing drowsiness
items.rationale: Silent chest with decreased mental status suggests severe airflow obstruction and impending respiratory failure. The other findings indicate improvement or stabilization.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Reduction of Risk Potential
items.stem: Which arterial blood gas (ABG) trend is most concerning for respiratory failure in a client with worsening acute asthma?
options: Rising PaCO2 with falling pH
Low PaCO2 with high pH
Normal PaO2 with normal pH
Mildly low PaCO2 with normal pH
items.correct: Rising PaCO2 with falling pH
items.rationale: As asthma worsens, the client may fatigue and hypoventilate, leading to CO2 retention and respiratory acidosis—an ominous sign requiring urgent escalation of care.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Basic Care and Comfort
items.stem: Which nursing intervention is most appropriate to help decrease the client’s work of breathing while treatments are being prepared?
options: Coach pursed-lip breathing and keep the client upright
Have the client lie flat to conserve energy
Encourage deep, rapid breathing to increase ventilation
Provide fluids orally to thin secretions immediately
items.correct: Coach pursed-lip breathing and keep the client upright
items.rationale: Upright positioning optimizes lung expansion and pursed-lip breathing can reduce air trapping and dyspnea. Lying flat can worsen breathing; rapid breathing increases fatigue; oral fluids may not be safe during significant dyspnea.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Reduction of Risk Potential
items.stem: The client’s SpO2 remains 89% on room air and they are tachypneic. Which action is the nurse’s priority while awaiting respiratory therapy?
options: Administer oxygen and apply continuous pulse oximetry
Delay oxygen until a provider evaluates the client
Obtain consent for intubation
Encourage the client to use the rescue inhaler from home
items.correct: Administer oxygen and apply continuous pulse oximetry
items.rationale: Immediate nursing actions include improving oxygenation and closely monitoring saturation in a hypoxemic, distressed client. Oxygen should not be delayed; consent for intubation is not the first step; using a home inhaler is not preferred over supervised ED-administered bronchodilator therapy.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Reduction of Risk Potential
items.stem: The nurse evaluates the client's presentation (RR 32/min, HR 118/min, SpO2 89% on room air, diffuse wheeze, speaking in short phrases, anxious). Which finding is most consistent with an acute asthma exacerbation causing impaired gas exchange?
options: SpO2 89% on room air with tachypnea
Blood pressure 128/80 mm Hg
Temperature 37.1°C
History of asthma treated with a rescue inhaler
items.correct: SpO2 89% on room air with tachypnea
items.rationale: Hypoxemia (SpO2 89% on room air) with increased work of breathing is the clearest indicator of impaired oxygenation during an acute asthma exacerbation; the other findings are non-specific or baseline context.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Pharmacological and Parenteral Therapies
items.stem: The provider prescribes initial emergency treatment for this client. Which intervention should the nurse anticipate and prepare to administer first?
options: Inhaled short-acting beta2-agonist via nebulizer with oxygen flow
Oral antibiotics for suspected bacterial bronchitis
Long-acting beta2-agonist inhaler for maintenance therapy
IV loop diuretic to reduce pulmonary congestion
items.correct: Inhaled short-acting beta2-agonist via nebulizer with oxygen flow
items.rationale: First-line acute asthma treatment is rapid bronchodilation with an inhaled short-acting beta2-agonist, often delivered by nebulizer with supplemental oxygen in the hypoxemic client. Antibiotics are not routine, LABAs are not for acute relief, and diuretics do not treat bronchospasm.
items.image_prompt: Create a realistic ER scene image showing a nurse preparing a nebulizer setup with oxygen tubing and medication vial at the bedside of an adult patient sitting upright, appearing mildly distressed and tachypneic. Include an oxygen flowmeter, nebulizer cup, and mask. No text on the image.
items.image_caption: Nebulized bronchodilator setup with oxygen delivery in the emergency department.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Basic Care and Comfort
items.stem: The client is anxious, wheezing, and speaking in short phrases with SpO2 89% on room air. What is the nurse’s priority first action?
options: Place the client in high-Fowler position and apply oxygen
Obtain a peak expiratory flow rate before any treatment
Encourage slow deep breathing into a paper bag
Offer oral fluids to thin secretions
items.correct: Place the client in high-Fowler position and apply oxygen
items.rationale: Airway and breathing are priority: upright positioning decreases work of breathing and supplemental oxygen treats hypoxemia. Peak flow is useful but should not delay immediate support. Paper-bag breathing is inappropriate and can worsen hypoxemia. Oral fluids are not the priority in acute respiratory distress.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Reduction of Risk Potential
items.stem: Which additional assessment finding most strongly suggests a life-threatening asthma exacerbation requiring immediate escalation of care?
options: Diminished or absent breath sounds with minimal wheeze
Productive cough with thick yellow sputum
Heart rate 102/min after treatment
Mild expiratory wheeze with ability to speak full sentences
items.correct: Diminished or absent breath sounds with minimal wheeze
items.rationale: A “silent chest” (markedly diminished/absent breath sounds) indicates severely reduced airflow and impending respiratory failure, requiring immediate escalation. The other findings are less consistent with imminent decompensation.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Pharmacological and Parenteral Therapies
items.stem: After the first nebulized bronchodilator treatment, which nursing action best supports ongoing management of this acute asthma exacerbation?
options: Administer systemic corticosteroids as ordered
Hold additional bronchodilators to prevent tachycardia
Discontinue oxygen once wheezing improves
Initiate chest physiotherapy to mobilize secretions
items.correct: Administer systemic corticosteroids as ordered
items.rationale: Systemic corticosteroids reduce airway inflammation and prevent relapse; they should be started early in moderate-to-severe exacerbations. Tachycardia may occur but is not a reason to stop needed bronchodilators. Oxygen is continued until oxygenation is stable. Chest physiotherapy is not routine for acute asthma.

Decrease oxygen flow to avoid suppressing respiratory drive
items.correct: Activate rapid response/notify provider and prepare for ventilatory support
items.rationale: Fatigue and decreased level of consciousness in acute asthma suggest impending respiratory failure; immediate escalation and preparation for advanced airway/ventilatory support are required. The other options delay care or are unsafe.

Mild metabolic acidosis with normal PaCO2
items.correct: PaCO2 rising toward normal or elevated with falling pH
items.rationale: Early asthma often shows respiratory alkalosis (low PaCO2) from hyperventilation. A rising or elevated PaCO2 with acidosis indicates ventilatory failure and is a worsening sign.

items.client_need: Health Promotion and Maintenance
items.stem: Before discharge teaching, the nurse assesses understanding of rescue inhaler use. Which client statement indicates correct technique for a metered-dose inhaler (MDI) with spacer?

“I will exhale into the spacer before inhaling so the medication mixes.”
items.correct: “I will press the canister and breathe in slowly and deeply, then hold my breath for about 10 seconds.”
items.rationale: With an MDI and spacer, the client should actuate, inhale slowly and deeply, and hold the breath about 10 seconds to improve deposition. Rapid inhalation reduces delivery; waiting about 1 minute between puffs is recommended; exhaling into the spacer is incorrect.

Inhaled long-acting beta2-agonist as monotherapy
Epinephrine IM for routine asthma symptoms without anaphylaxis
Supplemental oxygen to maintain adequate saturation
correct: Nebulized albuterol
Nebulized ipratropium
Systemic corticosteroid (IV or PO)
Supplemental oxygen to maintain adequate saturation
items.rationale: Acute asthma management includes short-acting beta2-agonists, anticholinergic bronchodilator (often combined in moderate-to-severe cases), early systemic corticosteroids, and oxygen for hypoxemia. LABA monotherapy is not used for acute exacerbations and is unsafe alone. IM epinephrine is not routine for typical asthma exacerbation (reserved for anaphylaxis or select refractory situations per protocol).

items.rationale: Clinical improvement includes better oxygenation with reduced support, improved airflow/peak flow, and decreased work of breathing with improved speech. Drowsiness and markedly diminished breath sounds suggest worsening and possible respiratory failure.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity - Reduction of Risk Potential
items.stem: The nurse assesses an adult with acute asthma exacerbation (SpO2 89% on room air, RR 32/min, speaking in short phrases, diffuse wheeze). Which assessment findings indicate impending respiratory failure requiring immediate escalation of care? Select all that apply.

Silent chest or markedly diminished breath sounds
Inability to speak more than one or two words at a time
Rising PaCO2 on arterial blood gas compared with earlier values
Peak expiratory flow improving to >80% of personal best after treatment
Severe agitation that progresses to fatigue and somnolence

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity - Pharmacological and Parenteral Therapies

Prepare to administer IV magnesium sulfate if poor response to initial therapy

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity - Basic Care and Comfort

Obtain IV access and administer systemic corticosteroid as ordered
Reassess response (SpO2, RR, breath sounds, ability to speak) and notify provider/RT for escalation if not improving
items.rationale: Immediate actions support airway/oxygenation and optimize breathing position, then rapid assessment and monitoring, then bronchodilator therapy, then systemic steroids after access is obtained, followed by reassessment and escalation based on response.

items.stem: Evolving case: acute asthma exacerbation

stages.update: Client arrives to the ER with diffuse wheeze, RR 32/min, HR 118/min, SpO2 89% on room air, anxious and speaking in short phrases.

question.stem: Which action should the nurse perform first?
options: Obtain a peak expiratory flow measurement
Apply oxygen and position the client upright
Start an IV and draw blood for an ABG
Provide reassurance and coach slow breathing

stages.rationale: Airway and breathing are the priority; oxygen and upright positioning are immediate interventions to improve oxygenation and ventilation before diagnostic testing.

stages.update: After oxygen and two back-to-back nebulized albuterol/ipratropium treatments, the client is still tachypneic and can only speak a few words at a time.

question.stem: Which actions should the nurse anticipate/implement next? Select all that apply.
options: Administer systemic corticosteroids as ordered
Prepare IV magnesium sulfate per protocol if no improvement
Hold further bronchodilators to prevent tachycardia
Continue frequent reassessment of work of breathing and ability to speak
Administer a benzodiazepine for anxiety
Notify the provider/RT that the client has persistent severe symptoms

stages.rationale: Persistent severe symptoms require early systemic steroids, possible adjunct magnesium, close reassessment, and prompt escalation/notification. Bronchodilators are continued as indicated; sedatives are avoided due to risk of hypoventilation.

stages.update: The client becomes fatigued; breath sounds are now diminished with minimal wheeze. ABG shows pH 7.31, PaCO2 52 mm Hg, PaO2 60 mm Hg despite oxygen.

question.stem: What is the best interpretation of these findings?
options: Improving ventilation with resolution of bronchospasm
Impending respiratory failure due to ventilatory fatigue
Primary metabolic acidosis from lactic acid buildup
Expected response to beta2-agonist therapy

stages.rationale: Rising PaCO2 with acidemia and a quiet chest indicates worsening airflow/ventilation and fatigue—impending respiratory failure requiring urgent escalation.

items.rationale: This evolving case emphasizes early oxygenation, timely bronchodilation and steroids, frequent reassessment, and recognition of rising PaCO2/silent chest as impending respiratory failure.

items.stem: Evolving case: escalation and safety during severe asthma

stages.update: Provider orders: continuous nebulized albuterol, IV methylprednisolone, and to consider noninvasive ventilation. SpO2 is 92% on high-flow oxygen; client is exhausted.

question.stem: Which nursing action best supports safe preparation for potential intubation?
options: Allow sips of water to prevent dehydration
Place the client NPO and ensure suction setup is available
Encourage the client to ambulate to mobilize secretions
Decrease oxygen flow to reduce risk of oxygen toxicity

stages.rationale: If intubation becomes necessary, aspiration risk must be reduced and airway equipment/suction should be ready; keeping NPO is appropriate.

stages.update: Noninvasive ventilation is initiated. After 10 minutes, the client is more somnolent and SpO2 falls to 88%. Chest movement is minimal.

question.stem: What is the nurse’s priority action?
options: Reassess in 15 minutes because fatigue is expected
Activate rapid response/notify provider immediately and prepare for intubation
Remove the mask and discontinue noninvasive ventilation
Administer an opioid for dyspnea relief

stages.rationale: Worsening oxygenation and somnolence indicate failure of noninvasive support and impending respiratory arrest; immediate escalation and preparation for intubation are required.

stages.update: After intubation, ventilator alarms indicate high peak airway pressures. The client is hypotensive and the chest is hyperexpanded.

question.stem: Which complications should the nurse suspect and report immediately? Select all that apply.
options: Dynamic hyperinflation/auto-PEEP
Tension pneumothorax
Pulmonary embolism as the most likely immediate cause
Ventilator-associated pneumonia developing within minutes
Barotrauma related to severe air trapping

stages.rationale: Severe asthma on mechanical ventilation can cause air trapping leading to auto-PEEP, high pressures, hypotension, and barotrauma including pneumothorax. VAP does not develop within minutes; PE is less likely in this immediate context.

items.rationale: This evolving case targets safe escalation (NPO and airway prep), recognition of NIV failure, and post-intubation complications from air trapping/barotrauma in severe asthma.

items.stem: Which statement by the nurse about blood pressure management in acute suspected ischemic stroke is most accurate?

Blood pressure should be lowered to normal range immediately to prevent brain swelling
Any systolic blood pressure over 160 requires immediate IV antihypertensive therapy before imaging
Oral antihypertensives should be given right away because the client missed amlodipine
items.correct: Blood pressure is often allowed to remain elevated initially to support cerebral perfusion unless there is another indication to lower it
items.rationale: Permissive hypertension is common in acute ischemic stroke to maintain cerebral perfusion; BP targets depend on candidacy for thrombolysis and other clinical factors. Immediate normalization can worsen ischemia.

items.correct: Ensure two patent IV lines are in place and the client is on continuous monitoring per stroke protocol
items.rationale: During emergent stroke evaluation, the nurse prioritizes readiness for rapid treatment (labs/contrast if needed, medication administration) and safety during transport (monitoring, IV access). Discharge planning interventions are not the priority.

items.correct: Findings are most consistent with an acute ischemic stroke and require rapid stroke protocol activation
items.rationale: Unilateral facial droop, slurred speech, and arm drift are classic acute stroke signs. The priority is rapid stroke evaluation (including last-known-well time and emergent imaging) because time-sensitive reperfusion therapies may be indicated.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity
items.stem: The client arrives to the ER with suspected acute stroke. Which action by the nurse best supports determining eligibility for thrombolytic therapy?

Administer aspirin 325 mg immediately
Lower the blood pressure to <140/90 with IV antihypertensive medication
Give oral fluids to prevent dehydration
items.correct: Obtain the exact time the client was last known well and document it clearly
items.rationale: Thrombolytic eligibility is highly time dependent; last-known-well time is essential to guide urgent imaging and treatment decisions. Aspirin is generally given after hemorrhage is excluded, BP targets differ depending on treatment plan, and oral intake is avoided until swallowing is screened.

items.rationale: A noncontrast head CT is the priority to distinguish ischemic from hemorrhagic stroke and guide time-sensitive treatment. Routine antihypertensive dosing is not first, anticoagulation is not initiated before imaging, and the client should remain NPO until dysphagia screening.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity

items.rationale: Dysphagia with coughing/wet voice suggests aspiration risk and potential airway compromise; the nurse should keep the client NPO and initiate swallow precautions. The other findings are not immediate airway threats.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity
items.stem: While preparing the client for CT, which nursing intervention is most appropriate?
options: Keep the client NPO until a swallow screen is completed
Place the client in Trendelenburg position to improve cerebral perfusion
Give the client sips of water to help with slurred speech

items.correct: Keep the client NPO until a swallow screen is completed
items.rationale: Stroke can impair swallowing; keeping the client NPO until a validated dysphagia screen reduces aspiration risk. Trendelenburg is not recommended, oral fluids are unsafe without screening, and heat packs do not address the acute neurologic emergency.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity
items.stem: The nurse receives a finger-stick glucose result of 42 mg/dL while the client is being evaluated for stroke. What is the nurse's first action?
options: Administer IV dextrose per protocol and recheck glucose
Proceed directly to CT because neurologic deficits indicate stroke
Administer aspirin and notify the provider
Give oral juice and crackers
items.correct: Administer IV dextrose per protocol and recheck glucose
items.rationale: Hypoglycemia is a reversible stroke mimic and must be treated immediately. IV dextrose is appropriate for a symptomatic adult and for a client who may not be safe to swallow; then reassess neurologic status and glucose.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity
items.stem: After noncontrast CT shows no hemorrhage, which statement is most accurate regarding blood pressure management if IV thrombolytic therapy is being considered?

Blood pressure must be lowered to ≤140/90 mm Hg before any stroke treatment
Blood pressure should be increased to improve cerebral perfusion
Blood pressure should not be monitored during thrombolytic therapy
items.correct: Blood pressure typically must be lowered to ≤185/110 mm Hg before thrombolytic administration
items.rationale: When IV thrombolytic therapy is planned, BP is generally controlled to ≤185/110 before initiation (and ≤180/105 after) to reduce hemorrhagic transformation risk. Lower targets such as 140/90 are not required acutely in this context.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity
items.stem: Which nursing action best supports accurate neurologic trending for this client?

Check pupils once on arrival and then discontinue neurologic checks
Limit assessments to vital signs to avoid overstimulation
Delay assessments until after antihypertensive therapy is given

items.rationale: Serial NIHSS assessments provide standardized trending of stroke severity and response to treatment. Ongoing neurologic monitoring is essential and should not be replaced by vitals-only checks or delayed without indication.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity

Check point-of-care blood glucose
Maintain NPO status until dysphagia screening is completed
Prepare the client for noncontrast CT imaging

correct: Activate the stroke alert/stroke protocol
Check point-of-care blood glucose
Maintain NPO status until dysphagia screening is completed
Prepare the client for noncontrast CT imaging
Place the client on continuous cardiac monitoring
items.rationale: Immediate management includes rapid stroke activation, glucose check to rule out mimics, NPO until swallow evaluation, emergent noncontrast CT, and cardiac monitoring for dysrhythmias (e.g., atrial fibrillation). Anticoagulation is not started emergently prior to imaging and definitive diagnosis.

History of intracranial hemorrhage
Current use of warfarin with elevated INR
Platelet count of 85,000/mm3

A missed antihypertensive dose alone is not a contraindication.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Reduction of Risk Potential

Perform a rapid glucose check
Establish two large-bore IV lines and draw labs per protocol

Aggressive BP lowering is avoided unless >185/110 when preparing for thrombolysis or another emergency indication exists.

items.client_need: Physiological Integrity: Pharmacological and Parenteral Therapies

A BP of 182/104 is below the treatment threshold (≤185/110) for eligibility.

items.client_need: Safe and Effective Care Environment: Management of Care
items.stem: Place the nursing actions in the correct order for this client with suspected acute stroke from arrival to imaging.
options: Check point-of-care blood glucose
Activate stroke alert and determine last-known-well time
Perform focused neuro assessment (e.g., NIHSS/FAST) and obtain vital signs
Establish IV access and draw labs per protocol

Rapid neuro assessment and vitals follow, then glucose is checked early to rule out/treat mimics. IV access/labs support reperfusion readiness. Noncontrast CT is obtained urgently to differentiate ischemic vs hemorrhagic stroke.
